etymologies: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin conventus ‘assembly, company’, from the verb convenire (see convene). The original spelling was covent (surviving in the place name Covent Garden); the modern form dates from the 16th century

definitions: a Christian community under monastic vows, especially one of nuns

examples.text: Maria entered the convent at the age of eighteen

shortDefinitions: Christian community of nuns living together under monastic vows

definitions: a school, especially one for girls, attached to and run by convent.
shortDefinitions: school attached to and run by convent

definitions: the building or buildings occupied by a convent

examples.text: the long windy path behind the convent

shortDefinitions: building or buildings occupied by such community
